facts.text: Appellant was Assistant Supervisor of Claim Cases of the Bengal Nagpur Railway (Vizianagram Section), later Eastern Railway, with power to deal finally with claims up to Rs. 75 and recommend higher claims to superior.
Appellant and V.S. Doraiswamy met in 1950; Doraiswamy working on behalf of persons with claims against the Railway.
Rs. 10 paid to appellant by Doraiswamy in October 1951, and Rs. 15 in January 1952, as gratification for speedy and favourable disposal of claim cases.
On secret information, Deputy Superintendent of Police, Special Police Establishment at Puri directed Inspector G.N. Brahma to contact Doraiswamy regarding alleged dishonesty by railway officials.

Brahma met Doraiswamy, who was asked to meet in Calcutta on May 10, 1952, after filing complaint with letters from appellant. Permission obtained from Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta to investigate.
Doraiswamy met appellant in Calcutta; settled to pay Rs. 100 on May 12, 1952, at 6 p.m. at India Coffee House. Doraiswamy informed police; given marked ten-rupee currency notes.
At India Coffee House, talk about expediting claim cases; Doraiswamy gave list of cases and bundle of marked currency notes to appellant, who put them in left upper pocket of shirt.
Inspectors H.K. Mukherjee, S.B. Mitra, G.N. Ghosh, and Brahma approached appellant, accused him of receiving bribe; after hesitation, he produced notes and list; numbers tallied.

Appellant convicted under s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and s.161 IPC by Special Judge; sentenced to 3 months RI and Rs.500 fine (default 1 month RI) under s.161; no separate sentence under Act.
Appeal to Calcutta High Court dismissed; judgment dated December 1, 1954.
High Court certified under Art.134(1)(c) Constitution fit for Supreme Court appeal, opining sanction may not be valid.
Sanction sought from Chief Commercial Superintendent Mr. Bokil (P.W.5), who was competent; he went through relevant papers, satisfied, and granted sanction (Ex.6).
Ex.6 states appellant demanded and accepted Rs.100 on May 12, 1952 as bribe for speedy settlement; Bokil applied mind, sanctioned prosecution under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) Act.
In cross-exam, Bokil stated sanction prepared by police, put by personnel branch; did not call for records or claim cases.
Concurrent findings of fact by courts below not questioned before Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was a valid sanction under s.6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, without which no court could take cognizance of the offences.

petitioner_arguments.text: No valid sanction under s.6 Act as Mr. Bokil did not apply his mind; cross-examination shows sanction prepared by police, put by personnel branch; did not call records or investigate claim cases.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947; Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King

respondent_arguments.text: Valid sanction as Ex.6 on face states facts, Bokil applied mind after going through relevant papers; cross-exam statements do not show lack of application of mind, merely no investigation of truth.

court_reasoning.text: Ex.6 clearly states all facts concerning the incident of acceptance of Rs.100 on May 12, 1952, Bokil applied mind and was satisfied in interests of justice; charge based on same incident.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sanction on face discloses valid sanction; Bokil's evidence confirms he went through relevant papers.

court_reasoning.text: Cross-exam does not prove mere mechanical signing; Bokil stated he reviewed relevant papers; no reason to distrust; not required to investigate truth or call records.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Officer of Bokil's rank would not blindly sign; papers provided necessary material.

court_reasoning.text: Gokulchand case not in conflict; sanction in keeping with Judicial Committee observations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sanction valid when scrutinized with Bokil's evidence.

holdings.text: Sanction accorded by Mr. Bokil is valid under s.6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction in this case in keeping with observations; does not conflict.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (II of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant convicted under s.5(2); sanction required under s.6; offence of criminal misconduct by corrupt/illegal use of position.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of accepting illegal gratification as motive/reward for official act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court certified case fit for Supreme Court appeal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld conviction and sentence, finding valid sanction under s.6 of the Act; dismissed appeal as concurrent fact findings not questioned and only issue of sanction resolved against appellant.

key_quotes.text: "before according the sanction he went through all the relevant papers and was satisfied that in the interests of justice the appellant should be prosecuted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms Bokil applied mind to facts.

key_quotes.text: "It is inconceivable that an officer of the rank of Mr. Bokil would blindly sign a ready-made sanction prepared by the police."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the sanction accorded was a valid sanction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on the legal issue.
